Iler, Robert L. and Janet L.
25th Anniversary
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--September 11, 1986
Iler, Robert L. and Janet L. of 742 Woodrich Street ,South West Massillon were honored at a surprise dinner party August 16 at the Mayfield Senior Center in celebration of their silver wedding anniversary The event was hosted by their children, Robert L. II and James W. Iler.
The former Janet Cline and Robert Iler were married August 20, 1961 in Canton Baptist Temple by Reverend Harold Henniger.
Robert retired in 1982 from the Republic Steel Company after 30 years service. He and his wife own and operate Perry Launderette in Massillon.
They are members of Canton Baptist Temple.
Mrs. Iler's parents were formerly from Monroe County, Jeanetta (Dillon) Cline of Massillon and the late James Cline.
Imhoff, Frank
 
Frank Imhoff, 84, of Powhatan Point, died Monday afternoon, June 22, 1964, at his home following a short illness. Born October 16, 1879, in Clarington he was the son of John and Mary Walters Imhoff. Mr. Imhoff was a member of St. John's United Church of Christ. Surviving are two sons, Dale Imhoff of Powhatan and Lester Imhoff of Louisville, OH; one daughter, Miss Laura Imhoff of Cleveland and two grandchildren. His wife Emma preceded him in death in 1951. Funeral services were held Wednesday afternoon at one o'clock in the Gibson-Bauknecht Funeral Home at Powhatan with Rev, Bernice Buehler officiating. Burial was in Powhatan Cemetery.

Jackson, Albert
Died: June 2, 1932
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Albert Jackson, aged about 78 years, died Wednesday morning at 5:30 o'clock at the home of his son, John Jackson of Jackson Ridge, after a two week serious illness.
He is survived by two sons, Charles and John of Jackson Ridge, besides many other relatives and friends. His wife preceded him in death about four years ago.
Funeral services will be held on Friday afternoon at the home at 1:00 o'clock with final obsequies at The Moffett's Church. Rev. A.O. Horney will be in charge of services.
A more complete obituary will be published later.

Jackson, Cora Ankrom
Woodsfield, Ohio - Cora J. Ankrom, 74, of the Monroe County Care Center died at 4:16 p.m. Wednesday (April 23, 2003) at the center.
She was born August 31, 1928, near Woodsfield to Jerry and Ida Baker Jackson. She was a homemaker and a Baptist by faith.
She is survived by two sons, Richard Ankrom and his wife, Connie, and Paul Ankrom and his wife, Rita, all of Woodsfield; one daughter-in-law, Sandra Ankrom of Woodsfield; and several grandchildren and great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Hila F. Ankrom; two sons, Hiram Ankrom and Earl Ankrom; her parents; one brother, Ole Jackson; three half sisters, Margaret Daniels, Martha Koontz and Estella Griffith; and one half brother, Lewis Jackson.
Services are at 11 a.m. Saturday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with the Reverend Earnest Hulsey officiating. Burial is in Neuhart Cemetery near Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at the funeral home. Source: The Marietta Times, dated Thursday, April 24, 2003

Jackson, James A.
Source--Wheeling News Register Wheeling, W.Va.
Published--Thursday, April 7, 1892
The Body of James Jackson Pulled Ashore in the Eighth Ward.
About 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning, James Nicholls, the collector for the Schmulbach Brewing Company, while standing upon the river bank, just above the Marshall county line, discovered a body floating down the river, about 100 yards from shore. He called to a man on the ferry-boat which was passing, but did not succeed in making him hear. Two young men had just landed with a skiff, and they rowed out, tied a rope about the body and pulled it to the shore. Coroner Phillips was notified by telephone, and responded in a short time. After viewing the body he had it taken to Altmyer & Myers' undertaking establishment, where it was prepared for burial. The corpse was neatly dressed, with black pantaloons, good lace shoes, and white shirt. The coat was missing and the vest badly torn. The man was evidently about 24 or 25 years of age. It was the general supposition that the body was that of Jas. A. Jackson who was drowned off the steamer Elaine, at Steubenville on February 9th. This supposition was strengthened by the fact that the deceased tallied with a description of Jackson, which has been published and posted all along the river in an offer of a reward by Hand-to-Hand Council, Jr. O.U.A.M., of Clarington. The relatives of the deceased were notified by telegraph, and yesterday afternoon an answer was received, stating that a brother of the dead man would come up last night to identify the remains.

Jackson, John W.
Fatal Accident
Died: July 29, 1931
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Injuries sustained in an automobile crash Saturday evening proved fatal to John W. Jackson,30, of Holliday's Cove, W.Va. He died Sunday morning at 5:25 o'clock. Death occurred at The Wheeling Hospital where he was rushed following the mishap.
Jackson, accompanied by George Wells. 21, of Stubenville, was driving north on Warwood Avenue, Wheeling. At North Twenty-third Street, he is thought to have failed to make the curve and crashed into Glenn's Run.
The automobile, according to witnesses, was traveling at a high rate of speed. The machine jumped over a six foot embankment and plunged into the run. Jackson and Wells were thrown clear of the auto, which alighted on its top.
Both men were rushed to the hospital. An examination revealed Jackson was critically injured, while Wells escaped with a few slight cuts and bruises. A post mortem, performed Sunday afternoon, revealed that death had been caused by an internal hemorrhage, resulting from a fractured ribs cutting the lungs.
Jackson was very well known. He was a foreman in the mills of Weirton Steel Company. He is survived by a wife and four children. The body has been removed to the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. B.S. Jackson, of Graysville. Funeral services were held Tuesday at The Woodsfield Church of Christ, in charge of Minister J. V. A. Traylor. Interment in Oaklawn Cemetery. Both grief-stricken families have the sympathy of many friends.
 
Jackson, Lawrence

1962

DEATH

Lawrence M. Jackson

A 61 year old Cambridge Route 3, farmer who was helping a neighbor put up hay, was instantly killed Monday evening when the farm tractor he was operating overturned, pinning him to the ground.

Lawrence M. Jackson was pronounced dead by County coroner Dr. W. A. Larrick. Death was due to a crushed chest, Dr. Larrick said.

Mr. Jackson had been helping out at the Walter Brothers farm on Route 3 when the accident occurred. He and a hired hand on the Brothers farm, Samuel Smith, also of Route 3, were reportedly working in a field about a quarter of a mile from the Brothers home.

According to Brothers, Mr. Jackson was apparently pulling a load of hay up a small incline when the tractor tipped over backWards on the driver.

The hired man walked the quarter of a mile back to the farmhouse where authorities were notified. The accident reportedly occurred shortly after 10:00 p.m.

Another neighbor, Donice B. Marlatt and his two sons went into the area and pulled the tractor off Mr. Jackson. They then took the body to the highway to await an ambulance.

Mr. Jackson a former employee of the American Culvert Co. was born February 21, 1901 in Monroe County, a son of Alva and Lottie Brown Jackson. He also formerly operated the Highland Dairy Bar.

Surviving are his widow, the former Bertha Carpenter; five daughters, Mrs. Genevieve Watson, of Ashland; Mrs. Geneva Miller, of Canton; Mrs. Olive Straquadine and Miss Dorcas Jackson, of Columbus, and Mrs. Rosetta McFerren, of Circleville; five sons, Charles and Richard Jackson, both of Ashland; Lawrence M. Jackson Jr. and Walter Jackson, both of Cambridge; Clarence Jackson, of Brownsville, Indiana; two sisters, Mrs. Lela Tubaugh, of Route 4, Woodsfield, and Mrs. Gladys Lude, of Moundsville, W. Va., and two brothers, Oliver Jackson, of Cuyahoga Falls and Carl Jackson, of Lewisville, Route 2.

Funeral services will be held Friday afternoon at one o'clock in the Scott Funeral Home at Cambridge with Evangelist William Craddock, of the Church of Christ, officiating. Interment will be in Friends Cemetery at Quaker City.

Jackson, Dr. O. C.
Published--1971
Doctor O. C. Jackson,87, of Woodsfield died Wednesday afternoon at his home after a long illness.
Born October 23, 1884, near Woodsfield, he was the son of Lewis and Jane Conner Jackson.
Dr. Jackson retired in 1967 after more than 40 years of medical practice in Woodsfield.
He was a former Monroe County health doctor, and a graduate of Ohio University and Augusta (Georgia) Medical College.
He was preceded in death by his wife in 1952.
Surviving are several nieces and nephews.
Friends may call at Bauer and Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield.
Services will be held at 2 p.m. Saturday at the funeral home with Minister J.V.A. Traylor officiating. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery at Woodsfield.

Jackson, Rollin
''Withered Flowers"
by Rollin Jackson
The weary soul of Harrigan's
Been mustered out at last.
The racking toil and hungry years
Are dim within the past.
And never more in life will he
Grow weak beneath the load;
His body's free of earthy toil
And he has found the road.
Somewhere beyond the wall that hides
The mystic, unknown realm
He's found the rest he never knew,
Unless in weary dreams.
His years of life were filled with toil,
His daily wage was small.
He never had half-decent clothes
To grace his form at all.
He seldom sat within a church---
A martyr to his pride---
For rags and toil in fancy pews
No longer can abide.
But in his honest, homely way
He measured up a man.
And if he failed to find sweet peace
No mortal can.

Jeffers, Mrs. Maggie Jeffers (nee Craig)
 
Source:Newspaper clipping, Monroe County Ohio, May 1894
 
We endeavor to chronicle the departure of our neighbor, Mrs. Maggie Jeffers. She was a daughter of John Craig and was born May 29, 1866. On July 13, 1886, she was united in marriage to Mr. Forrest Jeffers. She had been afflicted with consumption for the past year, when God said, " It is enough; come up higher," and on May 2, 1894 she peacefully fell asleep in Jesus, to await the resurrection of the just. She bore her sufferings without a murmur or complaint. She bade her friends and neighbors all good-by and wanted them to meet her in that better land. She was converted when sixteen years old to the M.E. church, of which she lived a consistent member. In personal character she was submissive and humble, always ready to administer to the wants of the sick and needy. Her private life is worthy of imitation. We can rise up and call her blessed. Interment at the Mt. Carrick cemetery. The funeral services were conducted by Rev. R. W. Martin.
 
She leaves a husband, two children, father, mother, one sister, three brothers, but we sorrow not as those who have no hope.
 
Dear wife and mother, fare thee well,
 
Thou are gone with Christ forever to dwell;
 
Thy work is done, thy troubles are o'er,
 
And may we all meet together on the golden shore. C.M.

Jeneskee, Prezalinski, Mrs. Anna, nee Jeneskee
Resident of Wheeling since early childhood succumbs Friday.Mrs. Anna Jeneskee Weings Prezalinski, 65, widow of Frank Prezalinski and a resident of Wheeling since childhood died Friday evening at 6:15 o' clock at her home, 4404 Wetzel Street. She suffered a paralytic stroke May 4 and a second stroke last night caused her death. Mrs. Prezalinski was born in New Jersey, Septemeber, 22, 1871, a daughter of John and Louise Jeneskee, and came to Wheeling with her parents when a child. She was a member of Immaculate Conception church and was affiliated with the P.T.A. of St. Mary's school. She was married to Mr. Prezalinski 50 years ago. He preceeded her in death 33 years ago. Surviving are 6 daughters, Mrs. Micheal Osmainanski, Mrs. Ann May, Mrs. Lawrence Manning, Mrs. Joseph Kuskey, all of Wheeling, and the Misses Bernadine and Marcella Weings, at home; 2 sons, John Prezalinski at home, Joseph Prezalinski, at home; 3 brothers, Harry C., William and Frank Janeskee, all of Wheeling; three sisters, Mrs. Mary Mulley, of Follansbee, West Virginia, Mrs. Lucy Dunn, of Sardis, OH, Mrs. Rose White, of Wheeling; 22 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. The body was removed to the Altmeyer funeral home and this afternoon was returned to the late residence. Brief services will be held at the home Tuesday morning at 8:15 o'clock. A mass of requiem will be celebrated at 9 o'clock in Imaculate Conception church. Mount Calvary cemetery will be the place of burial.

JEWELL, Elizabeth(Moores)Dunfee
Mrs. Elizabeth Dunfee-Jewell, aged 82 years, (Died June 17, 1913) one of Fort Wayne's oldest residents, died last night at 8 o'clock at the family home, 1920 South Harrison street. was due to heart trouble and followed an illness of several months. Mrs. Jewell had been bedfast for the past five weeks. Mrs. Jewell was born in Woodsfield, Ohio, November 22, 1830. Accompanied by her family, she came to Fort Wayne in 1876 and she had resided here ever since. The family is well known in Fort Wayne and Mrs. Jewell's comes as a shock to her countless friends. She was a woman of excellent character, loved by all who knew her. Surviving are two daughters and three sons - Miss Alice Dunfee, at home; Mrs. F.W. Dunham, of Stuttgart, Ark; Charles of Oakland, Cal.; Emmett W. of Jackson, Mich.; and Harry, at home. There are two brothers - Alfred Moores and John Moores, both of Fostoria, Ohio. There are also twelve grandchildren. The deceased was a member of the First M.E. church."
Source:Newspaper article
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson

Johnson, Harry M.
The Spirit of Democracy
Dated, January 14, 1943
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Funeral services were held on Wednesday afternoon for Harry M. Johnson, 41, who was fatally injured in an automobile accident Sunday morning near New Philadelphia. Brief services were held at his late residence near Lewisville followed by additional services at The Creighton Ridge Church. Rev. Arthur Weddle officiated. The body was brought to The Gardner Funeral Home at Stafford and on Tuesday was returned to the family home.
Surviving are his wife, Nellie Johnson; one son, Lloyd of the home; and his mother, Mrs. Anna Johnson, Sycamore Valley; five sisters, Mrs. Shelia Massie, Mrs. Ethel Unger, Harrietsville; Mrs. Ella Thurla of Cambridge; Stella Hubbard of Zanesville; and Hattie Smithberger of Sycamore Valley. One brother, Clarence Johnson, of Conneaut, also survives.
Mr. Johnson was employed in the oil fields of Brunswick. He attended Creighton Ridge Church. Burial followed in the church cemetery.

Johnston, Eleanor JOHNSTON b: 4 January 1828 in Woodsfield, Monroe County, Ohio
L.E. Johnston-----Died
(From a Tacoma Newspaper)
Published--The Spirit of Democracy Woodsfield, Ohio
Thursday June 20, 1918
Johnston
L. E. Johnston died at the Northern Pacific Hospital, Tacoma, Washington, Thursday, May 16th, of heart failure. He was aged sixty-five years, was a native of Ohio, and formerly lived in Good Hill. He was a member of The I.O.O.F. Indinola Lodge , No. 70, Iowa.Burial was in the Jacksonville Cemetery, Monday, May 20th. Mr. Johnston is survived by his wife, Mrs. Nettie Johnston.
Deceased was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Johnston of Woodsfield and a brother of Mrs. M. W. Baker and Mrs. William Read of Woodsfield and Mrs. Charles Sinclair of Summerfield, and Mr. W.H. Johnston of DesMoines, Iowa, who still survive.
Johnson, Enned F.
Source--Reed Funeral Home Memorial Obituaries Canton, Ohio
Published--February 15, 2005
Johnson , Enned "ED" F. , age 76, of Canton passed away in Hanover House Nursing Facility on Sunday, February 13, 2005 following a brief illness. Born in Monroe County, Ohio on October 11, 1928 to the late George and Opal Johnson, he was a 1947 graduate of Lincoln High School and went to serve his country proudly in the United States Army during the Korean War. Ed was employed by the Timken Company as an engineer, retiring in 1985 after 39 years of faithful service and was a member and past trustee of Mckinley Eagles Lodge #2370. Nothing met more to Ed than the time that he spent sharing his love with his family. His memory will be cherished as a loving father, grandfather, great grandfather, and brother. In addition to his parents he is preceded in death by two sisters, Janet Kinney and Phyllis (Liolios) Pertginides, brother, Everet Johnson and daughter-in-law Tracy Johnson. Survivors include two sons, David Rance Johnson of California., Robert Johnson of Perry Township., daughter, Lynn (Marvin) Guiler of Perry Township., brother, Louis (Ruth Ann) Johnson of Perry, six grandchildren, Matthew Hall of North Carolina., Marissa (Shaun) Riley of Massillon, Mike, Jason, and Kyle Johnson, Cassie Guiler and great grandson, Tyler Riley. There are many nieces and nephews also surviving. Funeral services will be conducted at 1 p.m. on Friday, February 18, 2005 in the Reed Funeral Home with Burial in Sunset Hills Burial Park. Calling hours will be in the funeral home on Thursday from 6-8 p.m. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to American Heart Association or American Cancer Society.
 
Johnson, Lucian M.
Lucien M. Johnson, aged 82 years, died at his home on High Street, March 23,1917, from pneumonia. Mr. Johnson with his wife came from Wheeling to Woodsfield 22 years ago. Mrs. Johnson preceded him to the world beyond one year ago. During their residence here they made many friends who sincerely regret their death. They were obliging and kind to all with whom they came in contact and always strove to find an oppurtunity to help some one. Mr. Johnson was a member of Wheeling Lodge 9 of The Independent Order of Oddfellows of Wheeling and was in good standing in his lodge at the time of his death. Woodsfield Lodge No. 377 I.O.O.F. took charge of the remains and had charge of the funeral which took place Monday afternoon. Rev. D. W. Harkins of The Church of Christ, who for many years was a close friend of the deceased, assisted by Rev.E.R.Romig of The M.E. Church, were the ministers. The interment was by the side of his wife in the family lot. The funeral was largely attended and the services by the ministers and Oddfellows very impressive. Mr. W.E. Wims, an adopted son, is left. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, March 29, 1917.

Jones, Audrey Hazel ( Thomas )
Source:Marietta Times . . . Marietta, OH . . .Mar 2002
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
RINARD MILLS - Audrey Hazel Jones, 96, of Ohio 260, Rinard Mills, died at 4:20 a.m. Sunday (March 10, 2002) at Marietta Memorial Hospital.
She was born October 17, 1905, in Bloomfield, Ohio, to David Everett and Ida Mae Hupp Thomas. She was a homemaker and a member of Muskingum Valley Baptist Church. She was an honorary member of Muskingum Valley Missionary Society and a member of American Legion Auxiliary 378 at New Matamoras.
She is survived by two sons, Paul E. Jones and his wife, Ruth, of Marietta and David Warren Jones of Rinard Mills; five grandchildren; three great-grandchildren; and two great-great-granddaughters.
On November 5, 1930, she married Ernest Dwight Jones in Marietta. He died June 18, 1980. She was also preceded in death by her parents; two sons, Bobby William and Franklin Eugene Jones; and one great-grandchild.
Services are at 2 p.m. Wednesday at Hadley Funeral Home, New Matamoras, with the Rev. Marvin Haught officiating. Burial is in Muskingum Valley Cemetery. The family will receive friends from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. Tuesday at the funeral home.

Jones, Ella.E., nee Hossman
Died, February 26, 1972
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Jones, Mrs. Ella E. Hossman, 80, of 5 twenty-third St., McMechen, died at 6 a.m. Saturday at home. Born in Sardis, October23,1891, she was a daughter of the late Godfrey and Lena Rufener Hossman. A member of The Church of Christ, McMechen, she is survived by her husband, Everett Jones; two brothers, Ernest Hossman,Glen Dale; and George Hossman, St. Clairsville; a sister, Mrs. Elinor Long, Cobb Island,Md.; and several nieces and nephews.

Jones, Jerry and Lisa Whitacre
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--Thursday January 9, 1986
Lisa Whitacre and Jerry Jones were united in marriage November 23 in the Methodist Church of Graysville. The Reverend Steve Sparling officiated the double-ring ceremony.
The bride is the daughter of Koy and Shirley Whitacre of Graysville and the bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Perley Jones of Rinard Mills.
The bride wore a lovely gown of Satinessa with beaded re-embroidered alencon lace. It featured a Victorian neckline and tapered sleeves with pouffed shirred shoulders. The beaded bodice had a fitted waist and chapel train. The bride's satin hat was beaded and trimmed with lace, with a large pouf in the back and a three foot veil down the back. She carried a bouquet of large white mums and minature red carnations with baby's breath and ivy.
Serving as the maid of honor was Jennifer Whitacre of Graysville, the bride's sister. Serving as best man was Carl Whitacre of Rinard Mills.
Music was provided by Charlene Sims. Kim Petty presided at the guest register. Guests included Paul Pastellak of New York, John Pastellak of Cleveland and Margie Ference of Pittsburgh.
A reception for the newlyweds followed in Graysville Elementary. The wedding cake was baked by Mrs. Myrna Starr. The food was prepared by the Low Gap Church Group. At the bridal party's table, seated in a high-chair was the son of the bride and bridegroom, Jamie Jones.
The bride is a 1982 graduate of Skyvue High School and Swiss Hills Vocational School. The bridegroom is a graduate of Frontier High School. Both are employed at Whitacre Store, Graysville, and will reside at Graysville.

Death Of Mrs. Jones
Died: July 4, 1931
Published July 8, 1931
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Mrs. Delbert Jones, aged 76 years, passed away at her home on South Paul Street, Saturday evening about 6:00 o'clock following an extended illness.
Mrs. Jones was a splendid woman and her passing brings grief to her many friends and relatives in Woodsfield and elsewhere. She was the mother of Sam Jones of baseBall fame.
Those left to survive are her husband, one daughter, Mrs. B. W. Hammett, of Medina, Ohio and five sons, Earl, Robert, William and Sam of Woodsfield and Charles of Niagara Falls. Two daughters preceded her in death.
Funeral services were conducted from the late home Tuesday afternoon at 2:00 o'clock by Rev. J. F. Cash, pastor of the M.E. Church, assisted by Rev. M. Danford. Interment in Oaklawn Cemetery.
We hope to publish a more detailed obituary notice later.

Kahrig, Catherine
Catherine Kahrig, the widow of Louis Kahrig died Friday, February 27, 1914, with pneumonia. She was born in Bavaria, Germany in 1849, and came to this country at the age of 5 years with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Adam Gertler. She spent her youth on the home farm near Lewisville, Ohio. Catherine married Louis in 1879. He died August 9, 1911. Eleven children was born to them; four preceded their parents in ; surviving children are: Mrs. Philip RHines, Fred Kahrig, Philip Kahrig, Mrs. Freda Wehr, Mrs. Gus Kilburn, Henry Kahrig and Mrs. Henry Kilburn; one brother, Adam Gertler of Ozark, Ohio; and one sister, Louisa Gertler ofBeallsville, Ohio, Ohio. Mrs. Kahrig was a member of the German Lutheran Church all her life. Funeral services were held at the Evangelical Church and was conducted by the Reverend E. Seybold. Interment was in the Oaklawn cemetery.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, February 1914

Kahrig, Frederick
Woodsfield, Ohio -Frederick Kahrig, 85, of Holiday avenue, Woodsfield, died at 11 a.m. Mon. (May 13) at Barnesville Hospital. He had been ill 12 years.
Born March 10, 1883 at Lewisville, he was he son of Ludwig and Catherine Gertler Kahrig.
He was a member of St. Sylvester's Catholic Church here, where he worked as a church Januaryitor before retiring some time ago.
Surviving are his widow, Teresa Burkhart Kahrig; a daughter, Mrs. James (Kathryn) Briggs of Ashland; a son, Walter, of Missoula, Montana; five
grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A daughter Louise and five brothers and four sisters are deceased.
Friends may call at Michener Funeral Home here anytime. Rosary will be resited at 7:30 p.m. Wednesday at the funeral home. Requiem mass will be celebrated at 10 a.m. Thursday at St. Sylvester's Catholic Church with Msgr. Robert A. Brown as celebrant. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery.

Kahrig, Gertrude Elizabeth, nee Christman

Woodsfield Gertrude E. Kahrig, 84, of 33181 Main St., Lewisville, died at 1 a.m. Friday, Jan. 27, 1995, at the Monroe County Care Center, Woodsfield.

She was born Jan. 7, 1911 at Lewisville, a daughter of the late George L. and Magdalena Matz Christman.

She was a retired store clerk at the former Reich s Market in Barnesville and was a member of Trinity United Church of Christ near Lewisville, where she was a former Sunday School teacher and a member of the Women s Guild.

In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Alfred W. Kahrig on Jan. 30, 1993; three sons, Marion Kahrig, Raymond Kahrig and Melvin Kahrig; one infant daughter; one sister, Esther Claus; two brothers, Arthur Christman and Clarence Christman.

Surviving are one son, Lewis W. Kahrig and his wife, Teresa of Woodsfield, Ohio; three daughters, Mrs. Thomas E. (Lena) Pettit) of Columbus, Mrs. Charles E. (Marlene) Caldwell of Pataskala and Mrs. Larry (Myrna) Gardner of Graysville; one brother, Paul Christman of Cambridge; three sisters, Elman Burkhurt, Laura Kahrig and Beryl Claus of Lewisville; 15 grandchildren, 11 great grandchildren and on great-great granddaughter.

Friends will be received at the Watters Funeral Home, 37501 Oho 78 West, Woodsfield, from 2 to 9 p.m. Saturday. Rev. Richard Wilson officiates the funeral at the funeral home at 2 p.m. Sunday. Burial follows in the Middle Church Cemetery near Lewisville.

Memorial contributions may be made to the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, car of Activity Center, 37390 Airport Road, Woodsfield.

 

 
Kahrig, Gottlieb
On Friday the 20th inst., Mr. Gottlieb Kahrig residing near Lewisville, Ohio, this County, came to Woodsfield on business connected with the alteration of a road. After he had arranged his business, he at 3 o clock Started home. When about one-fourth mile from town, he climbed over the fence into the field on the left of the road and had proceeded but a short distance when he fell dead. Mr. Louis Hoeffer was returning home from his school in the country, discovered Mr. Kahrig lying in the field. He approached and upon examination found that life was extinct, he immediately notified several men who were at work in the fields adjacent.
Information was brought to town, when Ed Salisbury, Esq., summoned a jury and proceeded to hold an inquest upon this body.
The finding of the jury was That Gottlieb Kahrig, whose body was found within a field near the town of Woodsfield in Center township, on the 20th day of March 1868, age 70 years, three months and five days, came to his by the visitation of God in a natural way, and not by means of violence. Mr. Kahrig was born December 15, 1797, in Rossnitz in the Kingdom of Saxony, the son of Johann George and Christina Sophia Farber Kahrig. He landed in America on October 9, 1838. He was married to Elizabetha Maria* Neuhart on September 23, 1841. He lived his entire life near Lewisville, Ohio.
The body of Mr. Kahrig was taken home Saturday morning. Interment was in the German Lutheran Middle Church, near Lewisville.
Source: Monroe County records and The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, dated March 24, 1868

Kahrig, Randy Neil

October 22, 1960

HOSPITAL

Randy Neil Kahrig

Source: Monroe County Beacon

Randy Neil Kahrig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Kahrig, of Lowell, Rt. 2, Ohio, will enter Children's Hospital in Columbus this Thursday(Octoberover 27, 1960) for surgery on both eyes.

Although Randy is only five years old, he has suffered with asthma since birth. In his five years he has been hospitalized seven times. He has had several injuries including a fall from a porch railing to the cement walk below, a distance of twelve feet.

Within the past year he has been bitten by a rare poisonous spider, had a head injury requiring several stitches, and had double pneumonia twice.

He may have been born under an unlucky Star, we do not know, but we do know that he will need and appreciate the prayers of loved ones and friends.

A card and coin shower is being planned for him by friends and they ask that mail be sent to his home.

Kahrig, Roger and Charlotte Mobley

October 30, 1960

WEDDING

Source: Monroe County Beacon

Miss Charlotte Yvonne Mobley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Mobley, of Lewisville, Route 2, and Mr. Roger H. Kahrig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kahrig, of Lewisville, Route 1, were united in marriage on Saturday afternoon, July ninth. Minister J. V. A. Traylor performed the double ring ceremony at 3:30 o'clock in the Church of Christ at Woodsfield.

For her wedding the bride wore a gown of white organza and lace. The bodice featured a round neckline and three quarter length sleeves. The full street length skirt was organza over taffeta. Her veil of silk illusion was held in place by a small cap of seed pearls. She carried a white Bible topped with pink Roses and showers of white ribbons and a baby breath. Her only jewelry was a single strand of pearls, and pearl earrings.

Miss Leora Kahrig, sister of the groom, was maid of honor. She wore a street length dress of yellow organza and carried a colonial bouquet of white carnations.

Mr. Woodrow Mobley, brother of the bride, served as best man. Immediately following the wedding a reception was held at the bride's home for members of the immediate families and wedding party. In the evening a shower was held in their honor and they received many lovely gifts.

The newlyweds are now residing at 427 East Main Street in Barnesville. Mr. Kahrig is employed at Sells Flower Gardens.

Kahrig, Walter F.
Walter F. Kahrig, 70, of Missoula died Saturday of natural causes in a local hospital.
He was born August 20, 1915 in Woodsfield, Ohio, to Frederick and Theresa Kahrig. He grew up and attended school in Ohio.
He cam to Missoula with the Civilian Conservation Corps and worked in a number of CCC camps in western Montana. He then was employed as a carpenter, working for several area contractors including Bolton & Tanner and Pew Construction. He retired eight years ago.
On March 10, 1959, he married Wilda Baker, in Wallace, Idaho.
Mr. Kahrig was a very active member of the Missoula Senior Citizens. He also enjoyed fishing and camping.
Survivors include his wife, Wilda, Missoula; a son, John Kahrig, Troutdale, Ore.; a stepson, Gary Baker, Lewisville, Ohio; a sister, Kathryn Briggs, Ashland, Ohio; and two grandchildren.
Funeral services will be at 11 a.m. Thursday at Squire Simmons & Carr Funeral Home with the Rev. Hugh Herbert officiating. Private burial will follow at Sunset Memorial Park. Pallbearers will be Willard Wylie, Chris Anderson, Charles Bagley, Bob Bondurant, Ed Johnson and Lou Shull.
Visitation at the funeral home will be from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. Tuesday and from 8 a.m. until service time Thursday.
The family suggests memorials to the Missoula Senior Citizens.
[Source: Missoulian, Missoula, Montana, Tuesday, December 24, 1985]

Kehl, Edsel Ira
Source--Akron Beacon Journal . . Akron OH . . Sept 1998
Kent, Ohio - Edsel Ira Kehl, 72, passed away September 16, 1998, with his family by his side.
Edsel was born March 9, 1926, in Noble County, Ohio, the son of Beulah (Day) and Darwin Kehl. Edsel served bravely in the Pacific Theater during World War II on board the USS Drew. He worked for Chrysler Corp. in Detroit and Harrisburg for 33 years. After retirement, he adopted golf as a hobby and spent many pleasant summer hours at Oak Knolls Golf Course in Kent, where he worked as a starter. He was a member of Rockton Lodge 316 in Kent and played golf in the Masonic golf league. Edsel enjoyed keeping in touch with old friends at USS Drew reunions and Chrysler retirees' luncheons. He loved following the Cleveland Indians through good years and bad and was especially happy to have attended division and American League playoffs and the World Series last year with his daughter.
Edsel had a kind heart and a generous spirit, and will be missed more than words can say by his wife of 39 years, Kathryn; and his daughter, Joyce of New York. Additional survivors include his sisters, Geneva Landefeld of Woodsfield, Darlene (LaVerne) Winland of Lower Salem; many nieces and nephews, and good friends and golfing buddies who were very supportive during this difficult time. He was preceded in death by his parents; sisters, Garnet, Norma Jean, and Delores; and brother, Earl.
Visitation will be at Bissler & Sons Funeral Home from 7 to 9 p.m. Friday. Graveside services will be held at 1 p.m. Saturday at Mt. Zion Cemetery near Harriettsville, Ohio. Donations to the charity of your choice. (Bissler & Sons Funeral Home, 330-673-5857.)

KENNEY, George W.
COMES AFTER STROKE
" Mr. George Kenney, past 80 years of age and for more than 45 years a resident of Washington County, passed away Wednesday afternoon at 2:10, at his home in Newport Township. being directly due to a stroke of paralysis suffered last Saturday evening, though he had been feeble for the past three or four years.
"Mr. Kenney was a stoneMason by trade, served one year in the Civil War, enlisting with the 116th Ohio Volunteer Infantry. He was born in Monroe County August 22, 1833.
"He was united in Marriage to Miss Nancy Morris, who died 39 years ago. Mr. Kenney was well known throughout the vicinity in which he lived and had many friends who will regret his passing.
"Six children survive. They are; George Kenney, Mrs. Adeline Campbell. Mrs. Anna Nothwang and Alice Mugrage, all of Marietta; Mrs. Mary Haddox, of Cambridge, and Edward Kenney of Belingto, VT. A sister. Mrs. Jane Haught and two brother, Joseph and Richard Kenney, reside in Graysville.
" Funeral services will be held Friday morning at 10 o'clock from the residence at Lower Newport. Burial will be made in Hill's Cemetery."
Source: Obituary, Marietta Times, Marietta, Ohio, 18 June, 1914

Ketterer, George F.
Source--News Clipping
Published--1955
Ketterer, George F., 89, who was active in Columbus Democratic politics for over thirty years, died on Thursday, February 17, 1955, in Grant Hospital, Columbus. He was a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Ketterer, of Miltonsburg.
Mr. Ketterer, who lived at 614 Sheridan Avenue, Columbus, was admitted to the hospital January 28. His wife, Julia, 79, died on Saturday, February 12th.
Mr. Ketterer went to Columbus in 1919 from Monroe County where he had served two terms on the county board of education.
In 1929, he was elected to a four-year term on the Columbus City Council, serving under Mayor James J. Thomas and Mayor Henry W. Worley.
Elected to the Ohio General Assembly in the Roosevelt landslide of 1936, Mr. Ketterer served two years in the Assembly.
For many years he was a Democratic ward committeeman on the East Side.
He was a member of the Grange, the Gold Leaf Society and the county Democratic club.
Surviving are a niece, Mrs. William Keyes, of Woodsfield; and two nephews, Myron Snodgrass, of Fairmont, West Virginia and Kennis S. Snodgrass, of Orlando Beach, Florida.
Services were held at two o'clock Saturday afternoon at the Schoedinger Funerla Home, Columbus. Entombment was in the Silent Home Mausoleum, Reynoldsburg.

Kettlewell, Charles Willia
Source--Columbus Dispatch Columbus, Ohio
Published--February 22, 2005
KETTLEWELL ,(Worthington Attorney ), Charles (Chuck) William Kettlewell, died Monday morning, February 21, 2005 at Riverside Hospital. Charles was born in Powhatan Point, Ohio on October 21, 1941 to Robert Simon Kettlewell and Neva Caldwell Kettlewell. Following undergraduate school, Charles married Marilyn G. Basnett and began four years of active duty with the United States Navy. He maintained reserve status with the military JAG corps until the early nineties, retiring with the rank of Captain. Charles was recognized nationally for his contributions to the field of legal ethics. Admitted to practice in Ohio, Oregon and before the United States Supreme Court, he was a co-founder and first president of the Association of Professional Responsibility Lawyers. (APRL.) Charles spoke frequently at APRL meetings and was instrumental in coordinating international legal ethics programs in China, Italy, England, Canada, and France. Charles was a partner of Kettlewell & Kettlewell LLC with his son Charles J. (Chad) Kettlewell. Additionally, he enjoyed teaching legal ethics as an adjunct professor for The Ohio State University College of Law since 1977. He is survived by his wife, Marilyn; daughter and son-in-law, Colleen K. and Robert Schriner; son and daughter-in-law, Charles J. and Susan Kettlewell; grandsons, Nicholas and Curtis Schriner. Additionally, he is survived by brothers, Robert E. Kettlewell of Gnadenhutten, Albert W. Kettlewell of Oxford; sisters, Alice Egy of Bloomingdale, Edna Giammarco of Steubenville, Edith Orkis of Pataskala, and Ruth Grieffenhagen of Wellington; mother-in-law, Clara B. Basnett of Worthington; and brother-in-law, R. Brett Basnett of Dallas, and their families. The family will be receiving friends 6-8 p.m. Thursday, February 24 at RUTHERFORD-CORBIN FUNERAL HOME, 515 High Street, Worthington. Memorial Service will be held at 10:30 a.m. Friday, February 25 at All Saints Lutheran Church, 6770 North High Street, Worthington. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Red Cross or Save the Children Foundation.

Keylor, Jacob C.
Jacob C. Keylor was born December 25, 1844, and died December 14,1917, aged 72 years, 11 months and 19 days.
August 15, 1862, he enlisted for service in The Civil War and served three years in Company A, 116th regiment Ohio Volunteer Infantry under Captain C. W. Ridgeway and J. Mallory and Colonel James Washburn. He was honrably discharged, June 14, 1865.
He was married November 7, 1867 to Malinda A. Harbin to which union seven children were born, five boys and two girls; Frank and Forest, and one girl,Rosa preceded him to the great beyond. He leaves to mourn his departure a widow, three sons, John, Charles and Willie; one daughter,Tillie; one sister, Jane Williams and four brothers, Frank, Samuel, Sinclair and Edward; eleven grandchildren and a host of friends.
The funeral services were held Tuesday and were conducted by the Gen. W. P. Richardson, G.A.R. Post and Rev. E.R.Romig. The county officials attended in a body and presented a fine floral piece in respect to the deceased who had been janitor at the court house for a number of years.
Mr. Keylor had resided in Woodsfield for many years and was known as a kind and obliging citizen and enjoyed the respect of all who knew him.
Those who attended the funeral from a distance were: Mrs. Mattie Yoho of Caldwell, Mrs. Tillie Carlisle and son Clyde of Lima, William Keylor of Lima, Mr. John Bach of Lima, Charles Keylor and son Floyd of Oklahoma and Mr. Ed. Keylor of Lewisville. Source: The Spirit of Democracy,

Clyde W. Kilburn
WOODSFIELD - Clyde W. Kilburn, 80, of 422 Moose Ridge Road died at 7 a.m. Wednesday (April 2, 2003) at the Monroe County Care Center in Woodsfield.
He was born Oct. 25, 1922, near Lewisville to Homer and Emma Bintz Kilburn. He was a United States Army veteran of World War II.
 
He was a retired employee of the Modern Hardware Store in Woodsfield. He was a former associate of the former Michener Funeral Home at Woodsfield and was an associate of Watters Funeral Home at Woodsfield since 1984.
 
He was a member of Woodsfield United Methodist Church at Woodsfield; American Legion Post 87 at Woodsfield; Monroe County Farm Bureau and the Farm Bureau Council; and member and past chancellor commander of the Knights of Pythian Lodge 338 at Woodsfield;
 
He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Fannie E. Fogle Kilburn; one daughter, Susan Adams of Fleming; two sisters, Mrs. Earl (Leona) Leach of Barnesville and Mrs. Robert (Rita) Winland of Bremen, Ohio; one grandson, Kevin Francis and his fiance, Shila Morrison, and her daughter, Kamryn, all of Newport; and several nieces and nephews.
 
He was preceded in death by one daughter, Mary Ann Kilburn, in 1962; and his parents.
 
Services are at 11 a.m. Saturday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with Pastor Dwaine Denis officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. Friday at the funeral home.

Kilburn, Estella Christman

Woodsfield-Mrs. Estella Kilburn Christman, 76, of Lewisville, died Sunday in Marietta Memorial Hospital in Marietta. (December 5, 1976)

She was born Oct 5, 1900 in Monroe County. She was a member of Lewisville Trinity United Church of Christ.

Surviving are a daughter, Mrs. William (Ruth) Seebach of Lewisville, two sons, Eldon of Lewisville Rt. 1 and Richard of Columbus; eight grandchildren; seven great-grandchildren; two brothers, Freeman Kilburn of Lewisville R.t.1 and William Kilburn of Cambridge; a sister, Mrs. Sylvia Armstrong of Alliance.

Friends may call after 1 p.m. today at Bauer and Turner Funeral Home here where services will be held at 1 p.m. Wednesday. Burial will be in Middle Church Cemetery, Lewisville, Rt. 1.

Kilburn, Gustav Frederick
Source--News Clipping
Kilburn, Gustav Frederick was born in Summit Township, Monroe County on June 13, 1873, the son of John Henry and Marie Linge Kilburn, and departed the life at his home on April 16, 1955.
He was baptized and a member in the Saint John's Evangelist and Reformed Church and at the age of 13 , he was confirmed.
On March 3, 1896 he was married to Miss Mary Kahrig by Reverend J.R. Muller. To this union 5 children were born. One child, Lydia preceded him in death in 1919.
Those who survivie him are Mrs. Freeman Christman, Freeman Kilburn, William Kilburn, Mrs. Sylvia Shull Armstrong; one brother Henry Kilburn and one sister, Mrs. Lucetta Kochart.
Kilburn, Gustav F.
 
Source--News Clipping
 
Published--1955
Kilburn, Gustav F., age 81, a retired farmer, passed away Saturday evening, April 16th, at 6:30 o'clock at his home in Lewisville following an extended illness.
 
Surviving are his wife, Mrs. Mary Kahrig Kilburn; two daughters, Mrs. Freeman Christman, of Monroefield, and Mrs. Sylvia Shull of Atwater, Ohio; two sons, William Kilburn, of Cambridge and Freeman Kilburn, of near Lewisville; one sister, Mrs. Lucetta Kochart, of Woodsfield, and one brother, Henry Kilburn, of Lewisville; fouteen grandchildren and sixteen great grandchildren.
 
Friends are being received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home.
 
Short services will be held in their chapel on Tuesday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock, with additional services at two o'clock in Saint John's (Middle Church) Evangelical and Reformed Church. Reverend George W. Varns will officiate. Burial will be in the church cemetery.

Kilburn, Harold R.
Source:Daily Jeffersonian . . Cambridge, OH, dated November 2001
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Woodsfield Harold R. Kilburn, 74, of Lewisville, died Thursday (November 22, 2001) at Marietta Memorial Hospital.
He was born February 17, 1927, in Cambridge, son of the late Freeman and Grace (Todd) Kilburn.
Mr. Kilburn owned and operated Lewisville Hardware for 17 years and retired to fish and farm in 1984.
He attended Lewisville High School and was a member of Trinity United Church of Christ, Lewisville.
He was a U.S. Army veteran, having served from 1945 to 1947 in World War II. He received the Army Occupation Medal for serving in Japan, the Asiatic Pacific Theater Ribbon and the World War II Victory Medal.
He leaves his wife, Judy (Ball) Kilburn of Lewisville, whom he married March 26, 1954; a daughter, Mrs. Denson (Sherry Lynn) Wright of Ellenton, Fla.; a son, Bryan (Christine) Kilburn of Lewisville; three brothers, Ralph (Birdie) Kilburn of Arizona, Donald (Judy) Kilburn and Dale (Dorothy) Kilburn, both of Lewisville; three grandchildren, Mrs. Keith (Kristy Wright) Gilbert of Springfield, Ga., and Kara and Chad Kilburn of Lewisville; and several nieces and nephews.
Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. today at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services will be 11 a.m. Saturday with the Revs. Jack Bruce and William Worcester officiating.
Burial will be in Middle Church Cemetery, Lewisville.
Memorial contributions may be made to Strecker Cancer Center, Marietta Memorial Hospital, 401 Matthew St., Marietta, OH 45750.

Kilburn, Mary, nee Kahrig
Published--1962
Mrs. Mary Kilburn, 84, of Lewisville, died Wednesday night at the home of her son ,Freeman, following a Long illness.
Born March 25, 1878 near Lewisville, she was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kahrig.
Mrs. Kilburn leaves two daughters, Mrs. Freeman Christman of Lewisville and Mrs. John Aiello of Alliance; two sons, Freeman, with whom she made her home. and William of Cambridge; two brothers, Philip Kahrig, of Lewisville, R.D.2 and Fred of Woodsfield; and 14 grandchildren, 35 great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild.
Brief funeral services will be conducted Saturday at 1 p.m. (DST) at The Bauer and Turner Funeral Home here by the Rev, Donald Stump with additional services at 2 p.m. at Middle Church near Lewisville. Burial will be in the church cemetery.
 
Kilburn, Preston Scott and Brittany Ann Roberts
Rodney and Tanya Roberts of Hannibal announce the engagement of their daughter, Brittany Ann Roberts to Preston Scott Kilburn, son of Stephen Kilburn of Lewisville and the late Darlene Kilburn.
Brittany is a 2003 graduate of River High School. She is currently a nursing student, expecting to graduate Belmont Technical College in August 2005, with an associate degree in applied science.
Preston is a 2001 graduate of Monroe Central High School. He is a 2003 graduate of The Ohio State University with an associates in applied science. He is currently employed with CTS Telecommunications in Cincinnati.
They are planning a fall 2005 wedding.
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, August 26, 2004
 
Kilburn, Ralph Emerson and Albert Stephen
On Saturday, June 18th, at 8:30 o'clock, Minister J.V.A. Traylor read the double-ring ceremony which united in marriage Miss Alberta Stephen, of near Batesville and Ralph Emerson Kilburn, son of Mr. and Mrs. F.G. Kilburn of Lewisville. The wedding took place at the Traylor home on Eastern Avenue.
The bride wore a street-length white knit dress with white accessories.
She was attended by Miss Peggy Lang of Quaker City, a close friend, who wore a two-piece gray gabardine suit with white accessories.
The groom wore a gray gabardine suit and was attended by his brother Harold Kilburn, of Lewisville, who wore a gray pin-strip suit.
Miss Stephen was graduated from Batesville High School, in the class of 1949. Mr. Kilburn graduated from the Lewisville High School, in the class of 1944.
After the ceremony a wedding dinner was served at the home of the groom's parents for the wedding party and close friends. Later they left for a short honeymoon to Niargara Falls..
Upon their return they will reside in Caldwell where Mr. Kilburn is employed as manager of the M.-K. Store.
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--June 23, 1949

Kindelberger, Rosena Agin x
Mrs. Rosena Agin, a life Long resident of Monroe County passed away at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Edgar Hall, on South Main Street, Thursday evening, December 23 at nine o'clock at the age of 83 years, ten months and nine days.
She was born near Coats Station, a daughter of Fred and Christina Kindelberger. She was one of eight children all of whom preceded her in death except one sister, Mrs. O. R. Baker, of Wichita, Kansas.
On September 10, 1885, she was united in marriage with Lewis Milton Agin who preceded her in death on June 18, 1927. To this union were born seven sons and three daughters.
At the early age of seventeen she was confirmed in St. Paul's Evangelical Church, later transferring her membership to the Neuhart Baptist Church where she remained faithful as Long as health permitted.
She leaves to mourn five sons and three daughters: Fred of Newark, Ohio; Charlie of the home; Mrs. Edgar (Lillie) Hall, of Woodsfield, with whom she made her home for the past three years; Clyde, of Circleville, Ohio; Roger of Norwich, O.; Mrs. Mark (Gladys) Nalley of Grandville, Mich; and Mrs. Carroll (Grace) Bishop of Mansfield, Ohio twins; and Arthur, of Grand Rapids, Michigan. Seventeen grandchildren and six great-grandchildren also survive.
Two sons, George, age 16 and Harry, age 3 preceded her in death several years ago.
Mrs. Agin bore her sickness with patience and with a smile for all. She was a kind and loving mother, always thoughtful of her children and others. She will be sadly missed by the children and all who knew her.
Brief funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at the Schumacher Funeral Home with additional services at the Neuhart Baptist Church, Minister J. V. A. Traylor officiated. She was laid to rest in the Neuhart Cemetery.
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, December 1948
Collection of gertrude Christman Kahrig, typed by Blanch Graham

Kindle, Homer
 
Apr 27, 1901
 
Sept 1971
Graysville
 
Death
Alva King aged fifty-five years, prominent Summerfield blackSmith and highly esteemed resident of that place, committed suicide at his home a few moments after the noon hour last Sunday by cutting his throat with a penknife, severing the windpipe. Almost an instant before he attempted to end his life by the use of shotgun, but the charge missed his head at which the muzzle of the fun had been directed. He then successfully used the knife, but no cause has been definitely assigned by his friends for his act. He is survived by his wife and one son, the latter being in the United States Navy.
Funeral services for Alva King or "Pat" as he was more familiarly known by his friends, were conducted at 2:00 o'clock this Wednesday afternoon in the Summerfield Methodist Episcopal Church by Rev. A.O. Rhodes pastor, assisted by Rev. J. D. Kaho of Berne, former pastor. Interment was made in Summerfield Cemetery. Wed. 28 January 1931 Noble County Leader Caldwell Ohio.

King, Eugene
Norton, Ohio-Eugene H. King, 70, died Dec. 9, 1994.
He was a life resident of Norton and area, retiring from Firestone Tire & Rubber after 40 years service. Mr. King was a World War II Army veteran and a member of Barberton Moose Lodge 759.
Mr. King is survived by wife of 50 years, Lucille; daughter and son-in-law; Pamela and Tim Farver of Wadsworth; son and daughter-in-law, Todd and Connie King of Clinton; grandchildren, Courtney and Andrew Farver, Stacey and Matthew King.
Funeral services will be Tuesday, 1 pm.m at the Campfield-Hickman Funeal HOme, Dr. Paul D. Outland officiating. Burial at Rose Hill Cemetery, where military graveside services will be conducted. Visitation will be Monday, 6 to 9 p.m. Memorials may be made to the American Heart Asociation (Campfield-Hickman, 745-3161)

King, Evelyn Ann, nee Schumacher
Beverly, Ohio- Evelyn Ann King, 77, of King's Drive died at 11:45 a.m. Thursday (October. 14, 2004) at Marietta Memorial Hospital.
 
She was born Sept. 5, 1927, in Woodsfield, Ohio, to Leo and Barbara Weisend Schumacher. She and her husband, Paul, had owned and operated King's Furniture in Beverly for many years.
She graduated from Woodsfield High School in 1945. She was a member of St. Bernard Catholic Church, the Catholic Women's Club, American Legion Auxiliary Unit 389 and the Beta Chapter of Ohio Child Conservation League.
 
She is survived by her husband, Paul E. King, whom she married on January. 28, 1948; seven daughters, Barbara LeMaster and her husband, Tony, of Marietta, Carolyn Schwendeman and her husband, John, of Decorah, Iowa, Mary Ann Mayhew and her husband, Edward, of Amhurst, Va., Yvonne Huck and her husband, Terence, of Beverly, Kathryn Wesel and her husband, Joseph H. II, of Marietta, Jaqueline Darden and her husband, Mike, of Tampa, Fla., and Christine Noel King of Beverly; three sons, Paul E. King Jr. and his wife, Barbara, of Houston, Texas, David King of Monroe, Va., and Jim King and his wife, Mary, of Sistersville, W.Va.; 31 grandchildren; 19 great-grandchildren; two sisters, Lucille Block of Cincinnati and Sister Evelyn Ann Schumacher of Manitowoc, Wis.; and one brother, William Schumacher of Woodsfield.
 
She was preceded in death by her parents; five brothers, Lawrence, Charles, Gilbert, Ambrose and Norbert; one sister, Mary Jennings; and one grandson, Matthew Aaron Schwendeman.
 
Services are at 10 a.m. Monday at St. Bernard Catholic Church in Beverly with Monsignor Robert Kawa officiating. Burial is in St. Bernard Catholic Cemetery. Friends may call from 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday and 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Sunday at McCurdy Funeral Home in Beverly, where a rosary service will be held at 8:30 p.m. Saturday and Sunday.
 
Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. Envelopes will be available at the funeral home. Source: Marietta Times, Friday, October 15, 2004

September 26, 1918
 
King, Russell O.
Russell O. King, aged sixty-three years, a well-known resident of the Hiramsburg community, died on Tuesday evening of last week at his home as the result of a stroke of paralysis suffered five years ago.
He was a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Amos King and was born in the vicinity of Summerfield where late he was a railroad section foreman for thirty-two years, locating at Hiramsburg twenty-four years ago. He is survived by his wife, thirteen children and two brothers, two sisters, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Funeral services conducted by Rev. Dwight James were held in Hiramsburg M.E. Church Saturday morning, and interment was made in Summerfield Cemetery. Wed. 19 August 1936 Noble County Leader.

Mrs. Samuel J. Roth, 58 years old, died at 12:20 AM yesterday, January 21, 1911, at Lakeview Hospital.  She was born in Ohio and was the daughter of Benjamin Kincade and she had lived here for the past 12 years.  She leaves the husband, Samuel J. Roth, 430 North Gilbert Street, and five children:  William Roth, Mrs. Charles Randall, Mrs. Frank Davidson, Pearl Roth, and Elmer Roth, the latter of Memphis, Tenn.  Also three brothers, N.J. Kincade of this city, Douglas Kincade of Toronto O., and Henry Kincade of Bellaire, Ohio survive.

Kinzy, Wayne, Mr. and Mrs.

APRIL 18,1974

FIFTIETH ANNIVERSARY

Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Kinzy

Source: The Monroe County Beacon

 

Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Kinzy, of Jerusalem, Route 1, were honored with a fiftieth wedding anniversary party on Friday evening, March eighth.

Mrs. Kinzy, the daughter of Sanford and Ethel Grim, the fifth of a family of fifteen children, and Mr. Kinzy, the son of J. V. and Anna Kinzy, were married at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1924, by W. R. Downer, Justice of the Peace.

Mr. and Mrs. Kinzy are the parents of seven children, Mrs. Annie Abbott, of

Beallsville; Mrs. Grace Stewart, of Jerusalem; Mrs. Phyllis Highman, of Columbus; Mrs. Sandra Koran, of Duchesne, Utah; John Kinzy, of Brock Ridge, Beallsville; Vernon Kinzy, of Akron, and Clinton Kinzy, the oldest, who was missing in action at Normandy Beachhead on D. Day.

Twenty-four grandchildren and twelve great grandchildren complete the family circle.

Kirkbride, Burnice
Published--June 1997
Burnice W. Kirkbride, 83, of The Monroe County Care Center, Woodsfield, died Monday, June 30, 1997, in Monroe County Care Center. He was a retired construction worker, a member of The Woodsfield Church of Christ and a veteran of World War II. (Born May 23, 1914)
He was preceded in death by wife , Velma Baker Kirkbride; an infant son; his parents Alonzo and Clara McElroy Kirkbride; two brothers; two sisters.
Surviving are a daughter, Patty Kirkbride of Woodsfield; a brother, Wayne Kirkbride of Woodsfield; two sisters, Martha Yoss of Monroe County Care Center and Vera Kanzigg of Ashland.
Friends were received Tuesday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services will be held today at 1 p.m.
Interment in The Jerusalem Cemetery, Jerusalem, Ohio.
Kirkbride, Edna R., nee Truax
Published--January 2003
Edna R. Truax Kirkbride, 92, of East Marietta Street, Woodsfield, died Thursday January 16, 2003 at Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center.
She was born February 21, 1910 in Monroe County, daughter of the late John Truax and Lorena (Henthorn) Truax.
Mrs. Kirkbride was a member of The Mt. Zion Church of Christ.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Isaac H. Kirkbride, in 1978; three sisters, Mildred Gates, Wilma Kindleberger and Fern Morris; and two brothers, Emmett and Wayne Truax.
She leaves two sons, Marvin (Lois) Kirkbride of Woodsfield and Ronald (Shirley)
Kirkbride of Jerusalem; a daughter, Mrs. Sonny(Patricia) Palmer of Woodsfield; a brother Carl Truax of Massillon; two sisters, Erma Jean Baker of Jerusalem and Betty Phillips of Apple Creek; six grandchildren; and six great grandchildren.
Friends were received Friday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services were held Saturday with Keith Jones officiating. Burial followed in Jerusalem Cemetery, Jerusalem.
Kirkbride, Ernest "Ernie"
SOURCE: Daily Jeffersonian . . Cambridge, OH . . Jan 2002
QUAKER CITY Ernest Ernie Kirkbride, 91, formerly of Quaker City, died Monday (Jan. 21, 2002) at Southeastern Med, Cambridge.
He was born May 26, 1910, in Belmont County, son of the late Ezra and Cora (Pittman) Kirkbride.
Mr. Kirkbride was a farmer and member of the East Main Street Church of Christ in Barnesville, and Seneca Valley Church.
He was a regular participant in local parades for many years, where he marched and played his harmonica.
He was preceded in death by two brothers, Isaac H. Kirkbride and Vernon Kirkbride; and a sister, Bessie Mayberry.
He leaves several nieces and nephews.
No calling hours will be observed. Graveside services and burial will be 2 p.m. Friday at Southern Cemetery, Somerton. Thorn-Black Funeral Home, Quaker City.
 
 
Kirkbride, Isaac
Source: Obituaries from Belmont County Newspapers,
Isaac Kirkbride, 71, of Jerusalem Route 1, died Friday afternoon, September 8, 1978, at Barnesville Hospital following a short illness.
He was born February 10, 1907, in Belmont County, the son of the late Ezra and Cora Pittman Kirkbride.
Mr. Kirkbride was a member of the Bush Church of Christ near Malaga.
Surviving are his wife, Edna Truex Kirkbride; ; two sons, Marvin Kirkbride of Woodsfield, and Ronald Kirkbride, of Jerusalem; one daughter, Mrs. Sonny (Patricia) Palmer, of Woodsfield; two brothers, Vernon Kirkbride and Ernest Kirkbride, of Quaker City, and six grandchildren.
Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at the Bush Church of Christ with Minister James Gallagher officiating. Burial was in the Jerusalem Cemetery with the Harper Funeral Home of Beallsville in charge.
Kirkbride, L. Grace, nee Warner
Published--September 1997
Collection of Cora Blackstone
Kirkbride, L. Grace ,84, 607 Cross Street, Summerfield, died Tuesday, September 2,
1997 at Marietta Memorial Hospital, Marietta. She was born December 9, 1912 in Noble County, daughter of the late James and Minnie Curry Warner.
She had been a patient at Summit Acres Nursing Home, Caldwell since June 1997. She was a homemaker and a member of The Summerfield Church of Christ, Summerfield.
She was also a member of the Noble County Senior Citizens in Caldwell.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Monzona Kirkbride on November 4, 1991; two brothers, Frank Warner and Grant Warner and one step great-grandaughter, Deanna Smithberger.
Surviving are three daughters, Ethel Weisend of Newark, Lela Hill and her husband, Bernard and Donna Mallett and her husband, Larry , all of Summerfield; one son, Donald Kirkbride and his wife Linda of Whipple; three sisters, Dorothy Carpenter of Summerfield,

Koehler, Charles Koehler
April 1, 1923
 

APRIL 11, 1974

TRAILER HOME DESTROYED

Source: The Monroe County Beacon

 

Although Monroe County was fortunate in being spared the widespread devastation that hit other parts of Ohio in last week's storm, there were a great many instances of damage.

Shown here is the trailer home of Mrs. Estella Koehler, located on Middle Church Road, County Road 18, 4.5 miles north of Lewisville. Mrs. Koehler had fortunately gone to her daughter's home next door, that of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Kilburn, when the storm became intense. The trailer was leveled at about 2:45 a.m. on April 4, 1974.

Kremer, GeorgeA. and William C. Kremer
Kremer Brothers German Prisioners
Published--January 15, 1945
Judge and Mrs. T.J. Kremer received a telegram from the War Department Wednesday morning stating: "Report has just been received from the German Government through the International Red Cross that your sons, 1st. Lieuts. William C. and George A. Kremer are prisoners of war of that Government. Letter follows from Provost Marshall General, Washington, furnishing instructions as how you may communicate with your sons."
On January 5th, Judge and Mrs. Kremer received word that their sons, both B-24 Commanders, stationed at a heavy bombardment base of the 15th AAF in Italy, were missing in action since December 15 in a raid over Austria. They later learned they were both on the some plane, Lt. George Kremer, being the pilot, and Lt. William Kremer, the co-pilot.
The Kremer brothers have been together since pre-flight school. They soloed at the same time and graduated as combat pilots from advanced flying school at Lubbock Field, Texas, together, February 8, 1944.
from the collection of gertrude Christman Kahrig, typed by betty lendon matson.

Kress, George and Oscar
Meet in Manilla Bay
George Kress, Seaman & Sgt. Oscar Kress
Published-- 1945
George Kress, seaman, first class, and Sergeant Oscar Kress, sons of Mrs. Margaret Kress, of Woodsfield, met in Manila Bay the first part of September while Oscar was on a four-hour pass. It was the first time the brothers had met in two years.
Seaman Kress, who is attached to a merchant ship, entered the Navy September 23, 1943, receiving his boot training at Great Lakes, Illinois. He saw action in the Atlantic area and for the past year has been in the Pacific area. He has two battle Stars, one for the invasion of France, and the other for the Philippines. He is now enroute to the United States. His wife and little son, Freddie, reside near Miltonsburg.
Sergeant Kress, who was inducted into the Army October 14, 1942, has been in the Southwest Pacific for the past 18 months. He has been on Luzon since January 9th. He also has two battle Stars, one for New Guinea and the other for the Philippines. He also has the Good Conduct Medal.
Another brother, T/Sgt. Gilbert E. Kress, was discharged from the A.A F. at the Separation Center at Sheppard Field, Texas.
from the collection of gertrude Christman Kahrig, ty[ped by betty lendon matson

Kress: Gilbert E.
Crew Cheif On Medium Bomber
T. Sgt. Gilbert Kress
Published---1943
Gilbert E. Kress, son of Margaret Kress, of Woodsfield, joined The United States Army Air Corps in 1940 at Columbus, Ohio. He was sent to Maxwell Field, Ala.,for basic training, then to Jefferson Barracks, Mo., in December 1940, and to Chanute Field, Ill., on January 4, 1941, to attend airplane mechanics school. He graduated from there in July and was made an instructor in airplane mechanics.
He remained an instructor there until October 1, 1941, when he was sent to Sheppard Field , when he was sent to Sheppard Field, Texas, as an instructor. During his time there, he returned to Chanute Field for a special course in aircraft engines, then he was sent to the school at Armarillo, Texas, on September 12,1942. He was picked for aerial gunner and sent to Harlington Field, Texas, graduating on December 16, 1942 and received his "Silver Wings'. He was sent to Columbia Air Base, South Carolina, on December 20, 1942, as a crew chief on a medium bomber.
During his army career, he has been promoted five times, first on July 1, 1941 to Private First Class, to Corporal on February 1, 1942, to Sergeant in April 1942, to Staff Sergeant in December ,1942 and to Technical Sergeant, May 25,1943.
Gilbert's address is : T. Sgt. Gilbert E. Kress, 376 Bomb Squadron, 309 Bomb Group, C.A.A.B., Columbia, South Carolina.
Gilbert has one brother serving in The Unites States Army. He is Private Oscar Kress,
Headquarters Battery, 16th F.A. Obsn., Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri.

Krieg,Dr. H. Lester
PLANO, Texas - Dr. H. Lester Krieg, 92, former resident of Marietta, died Tuesday (Feb. 15, 2005) in Plano, Texas, where he had made his home in recent years.
He was born June 19, 1912, in Monroe County, Ohio, a son of Henry and Alma Frobisch Krieg, who preceded him in death. He was a graduate of Ohio State University School of Dentistry and practiced in Marietta until his retirement in 1987. He was a longtime member of the Marietta Noon Lions Club and was a past district governor. He was a devout member of St. Paul's Evangelical Church and held many positions in the church.
On June 21, 1941, he married Violette Trepanier, who preceded him in death on July 25, 1989. He is survived by his daughter, Michele Krieg Bauer, and his grandson, Joshua Bauer, of Dallas, Texas.
Funeral services will be held at 2 p.m. Friday at St. Paul's Evangelical Church at 401 Fifth St. with Pastor Steven Dennis officiating. Interment will be in Mound Cemetery. Kuhn, Pfc. Herman A. Kuhn
Published---1943
Pfc. Herman A. Kuhn, U.S. Marine Corps, son of Mr. and Mrs Joseph A. Kuhn, of Lewisville, Route 1, was killed in action September 21st in The Invasion of Pelelieu Island. His parents received the telegram announcing his death on October 6. The last letter relatives received from him was dated September 14.
Pfc. Kuhn was born September 17, 1917. He enlisted in The U.S. Marine Corps, January 19, 1942, receiving his basic training in San Diego, California, and leaving for overseas on October 10, 1942, never having had a furlough. He participated in several major battles, including Guadalcanal, New Britain, New Guiena and Palaus Islands. He was in Austrailia for a rest period, and had malaria several times.
A memorial service was held on Monday morning, October 9th, at 8:30 o'clock in St. Joseph's Church, at Burkhart, with Rev. Joseph Finan officiating at a Requiem High Mass.
Surviving are his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kuhn; and the following sisters and brother; Mrs. Earl Norris, of Zanesville; Mrs. Francis Dimmerling, of Summerfield; Misses Matilda and Nellie Kuhn, of Zanesville, and Mark Kuhn, of the home.

Marriage
KUHN, Miss Joan Kuhn Weds Andrew Miller
In St. Joseph's Church at Burkhart
Published--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Thursday August 17, 1950
In St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Burkhart, Saturday morning, June seventeenth, Miss Joan
Kuhn, the daughter of Mrs. Edna Masciarelli, of Lewisville, became the bride of Andrew Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Miller, of Harrietsville.
The double ring ceremony and Nuptial High Mass was solemnized at nine o'clock by the Rev. Joseph Finan. The church was beautifully decorated with mixed summer flowers, and greenery was used on the altars.
Mrs. HoWard Rucker, organist, played the traditional wedding marches for the processional
and recessional. Dale Latimer, vocalist , sang " Ava Maria" at the Offertory, being accompanied by Gene Huffman. The hymn " On This Day Oh Beautiful Mother" was sung by The Burkhart Girls Choir at the conclusion of the ceremony.
The bride chose for her wedding a gown of sheer nylon marquisette over a taffeta slip, styled with a pre Victorian collar, sweetheart neckline and three-quarter length sleeve
transcending in a ruffle made of Rose lace. The fitted bodice was trimmed with small covered buttons extending to the waistline. The full skirt terminated into a Long train. Her net finger-tip veil fell from a tiara of White pearl flowers with settings. Her only jewelry was a single strand of pearls with matching tiny earrings. She carried a White Bible topped with American Beauty Tea Rosebuds and forget-me-nots with White silk streamers. The bride followed the tradition of something old, new, borrowed and blue.
Miss Mary Evelyn Kuhn, maid of honor, wore a gown of blue marquisette over a taffeta slip, styled with a modified hoop skirt. A cape of net covered the top of the gown,and a spray of flowers edged the neckline. Her large picture hat matched her gown. She carried a Colonial bouquet.
Ralph Miller served his brother as best man. Both the groom and best man wore blue suits
with a White cArnation in their lapel.
The ushers were Ward Wilson and Clarence Brubach, of Summerfield.
The bride's wore a suit a suit of gray whipcord with White accessories. The groom's mother was attired in a lavender eyelet dress with White accessories. Their corsages were of American Beauty Tea Rosebuds.
A reception was held in the Parish Hall. The room was decorated in blue and White. A three-tiered wedding cake, topped with a miniature bride and groom, centered the bride's table, with bouquets of mixed flowers on either side. Assisting at the reception were the members of Mrs. Masciarelli's club. Immediately following the dinner the gifts were opened.
Gene Huffman softly played a medley of appropriate selections during the dinner.
In the evening a round and square dance was held. As the bride and groom entered the hall the orchestra played "Here Comes The Bride".
Mr. and Mrs. Miller are now residing at 205 1/2 Montgomery Street, Marietta.
Guests attending the wedding were: Mrs. Ross Latimer, Dale Latimer, Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Crock, of Woodsfield ; Ward Wilson, Clarence Brubach, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Yontz, of Summerfield; Miss Virginia Lawley and Mrs. Ralph Carpenter of Lewisville; Mr. and Mrs Pete Masciarelli and son Marion of Bellaire; Mr.and Mrs. Gerald Miller and son David, Lillian Miller and Clarence Bettinger, Caldwell; Joan Miller, Harold Nau and Wilma Nau of Dexter City; Mr. and Mrs. Carl Russell and twins Becky and Rodney, of Ravenna;
Gene Huffman of Antioch; Rev.A.G.Nickel, Mr. and Mrs. Alex Miller, Donald Miller, of Harrietsville; Mrs. Delores Burkhart of Miltonsburg; Mrs. Elizabeth Miller and Mrs. G.W.
Morrison, Zanesville; Mr. and Mrs. Fred Warner and daughter, Ruth, of Berne.
Kenneth Kuhn, Joseph Kuhn, Mr. and Mrs. Alex Ulrich and children, Ruth Stimpert, Lucy Kuhn, Mary J. Kuhn, Monica Ulrich, James Kuhn, Rose Ann Kuhn, Mrs. S.T. Kuhn,Elizabeth Schwallie, Patty Kuhn, Judith Kay Masciarelli, Rita Kuhn, Nickie Masciarelli, Mrs.Minnie Ulrich, Esther Lee Masciarelli, Mrs. Justina Kuhn, Mr. and Mrs.Nick Masciarelli, Norma Jean
Miller, Mr.and Mrs. C.D. McKinney, Diana Masciarelli, Donna Nau, Charlene Scott, Mary Kuhn, Catherine Miller, Carol Kuhn, Shirley Miller, Mr. and Mrs. Leander Kuhn, Mrs. Ward Bishop, Mrs. Harmon Scott, Mrs. Lyle Weisend, Mrs. Okey Ruble, Mrs. Arthur Kuhn and Mrs. Leland Johnson.

April 3, 1924
Lewisville Fire
A fire alarm was turned in from the home of Will Laffarre, postmaster of Lewisville last Monday night at 11 o'clock. The local bucket brigade turned out promptly and but little if any damage was done to the home. The fire originated from a defective flue.

WOOSTER - Hazel Beatrice Lallathin, 90, a former resident of Marietta, died early Wednesday morning (October 30, 2002) at Wooster Hospital in Wooster, Ohio. Her home had been at Rinard Mills and later in Marietta before going to Wooster 11 years ago to be cared for after receiving injuries in a fall at her home in Marietta. She had been a resident of Shady Lawn Nursing Home for 11 years.

Landefeld, Miss Clara and Mr. Charles W. Stegner
Source:The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., June 22, 1916
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Miss Clara LANDELFELD, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August LANDEFELD, whose home is near Miltonsburg, Ohio and Mr. Charles W. STEGNER, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. E. STEGNER of Columbus, Ohio former well known citizens of Monroe County, were united in marriage Wednesday, June 14, 1916, at the home of the groom s sister, Mrs. E. G. CUNNINGHAM of South Paul Street, in the presence of a few immediate relatives. The Reverend E. N. KRAFFT of Lewisville officiated, using the beautiful ritual service of the Evangelical Church. After the ceremony and congratulations Mrs. Cunningham served an excellent three course wedding dinner. Later in the afternoon Mr. and Mrs. STEGNER were taken to the home of his bride s parents where they were entertained in the evening. Both are members of two of Monroe County s best families and in themselves are well worthy of the confidence and esteem in which they are held by their friends in their home communities. They will be at home at their friends in Columbus after June 25th at 74 North Ohio Avenue, as they expect to make that city their home. Mr. STEGNER has a good position with a hardware firm and his experience and efficiency will insure his making good with the people by whom he is employed.

Married in Somerton Church of Christ
Published---1964
Miss Juanita Darlene Landefeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence L. Landefeld, of Woodsfield, Route 3, became the bride on Saturday evening, February 22, of Ronald Earl Thornberry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn E. Thornberry, of Somerton. Evangelist McKinley R. Bates performed the double ring ceremony before members of the immediate families at half past six o'clock in The Somerton Church of Christ.
For her wedding the bride chose a Ballerina length gown of lace over taffeta. The fitted bodice was designed with scalloped neckline outlined with tiny seed pearls and sequins, and three-quarter length sleeves. The bell shaped skirt featured a chiffon bow with streamers in the back to the hemline of the skirt. Her veil of silk illusion was held in place by a crown of tiny seed pearls and sequins. She wore a single cultured pearl, a gift of the bridegroom, and carried a colonial bouquet of pink and White carnations with pink streamers. Mrs. Edward Long, sister of the bridegroom, of Mansfield, served as matron of honor. She wore a street-length sheath dress of poudre blue mohair with matching accessories and carried a bouquet of light blue and White carnations. Mr. Edward H. Long, brother-in-law of the bridegroom of Mansfield, was best man.
Mrs. Landefeld, the bride's mother, wore a royal blue mohair sheath dress with black accessories. Mrs. Thornberry, the bridegroom's mother, wore a winter White sheath dress with taupe accessories. Both mothers wore corsages of blue and White carnations.
Immediately following the wedding, a reception was held at Belmont Grange Hall, east of Barnesville. The bride's table was centered with a three-tiered wedding cake, topped with minature bride and groom in a lace heart. Reception hostesses were: Miss Linda Frietag, Miss Judy Carleton, Mrs. Aaron Brown, Mrs. James Williamson and Mrs. Junior Clift. Others assisting were Mrs. Carl Wade and Mrs Oliver Clift. Miss Harriet Thornberry, sister of the bridegroom, was in charge of the guest book. She wore a red wool sheath dress and a corsage of White carnations.
Before leaving on a wedding trip, the new Mrs. Thornberry changed to a winter White mohair sheath dress with tan accessories and wore a corsage of yellow carnations.
The bride is a graduate of Woodsfield High School, class of 1963, and is employed with LGAM Manufacturing Company, Woodsfield. The bridegroom graduated from Barnesville High School, class of 1962, and is employed with A & L Builders, Somerton.
The young couple is presently residing in Somerton.
Guests attending the wedding and reception were from; Barnesville, Woodsfield, Jerusalem, Somerton, Malaga, Boston, Belmont, Bridgeport, Miltonsburg, Akron, Mansfield, Arlington, Virginia and Kentucky.

Lashley, Faye Rowley
Published---1938
Faye Rowley Lashley, the eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F.C. Rowley, was born February 18, 1901, and departed this life at the home she loved so well near Jerusalem,
Octoberober 22, 1938, being at the time of her death, 37 years, 8 months, and 4 days. She had been in ill health for several years but was serious for the last five months. All that medical skill and love could do, was to no avail.
She obeyed The Gospel in early womanhood being united with The Church of Christ.
On November 18, 1933, she was united in marriage to Thomas Lashley. To this union were born three sons, Billy, Tommy and Jimmy, who preceded her in death in infancy.
She leaves to mourn her loss, her husband and sons, Billy, age 4 years, and Tommy, age 9 months; Mrs. Ella Rowley, her mother; two sisters, Miss Jeane Rowley, of the home; Mrs. Madge Stough, of Tionesta, Pennsylvania, and one brother, Russel Rowley, of Jerusalem. Her father preceded her in death six years ago. A number of other relatives and friends also survive.
She was a successful school teacher having taught in this and surrounding counties for several years.
Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon, October 25th, at 2:00 o'clock at The Jerusalem Presbyterian Church, Minister J.V.A. Traylor, of The Woodsfield Church of Christ officiating. Interment was made in The Jerusalem Cemetery.
Those attending the funeral from a distance were: Mr. and Mrs. Guy Stough and daughter Joan and little Tommie Lashley, of Tionesta, Pa.; Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Crozier, Mrs.Robert M. Crozier, Mrs. Reuben Riggs and sons, of Bellaire; Mr. and Mrs. Fred Yockey, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Yockey, of Barnesville; Mr. and Mrs. Clark Wilcox and son Clarence of Barnesville; Mr. and Mrs Fred Sayres and Isaac Lashley, of Canton; Mr. and Mrs. Fred Pyles.

Latta, Thomas L.
Thomas L. Latta -- accident
 
Source: The Monroe Courier, Jan. 12,1912
 
Examiner Latta Hurt
 
On his way from Miltonsburg to Woodsfield last Friday to assist in holding the monthly school examination, Prof. T. L. Latta, vice president of the board of school examiners, met with a painful accident. The horse that he was riding fell in such a manner as to throw Mr. Latta on the frozen ground with such violence that several ugly gashes were cut in his face and he was otherwise badly bruised. Several stitches were required to close some of the cuts; but the professor demonstrated some grit in attending to his duties as examiner Saturday.s

He was born May 4, 1941, in Asco, W.Va., son of Lora Edna (Hylton) Laxton of Martinsville, Va., and the late George A. Laxton.
